title: Re-writing of import paths causes failures since they're re-written after a file save which causes failures on fast rebuilds such as webpack or parcel running
body:
Issue Type: Bug INTRO: I love this overall feature please keep it. https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_24#_update-import-paths-when-a-file-is-moved-or-renamed However ... Re-writing of import paths causes failures since they're re-written after a file save which causes failures on fast rebuilds such as webpack or parcel running. This is a fun bug. Let me know if you can reproduce this. It basically goes like this - 1. Create an empty project that uses parcel. 2. Create a `src/foo.js` 3. Create a `src/bar.js` 4. Open `foo.js` and add an `import bar from './bar.js'` 5. Open an integrated terminal and start parcel. At this point parcel is rebuilding exceptionally quickly. 6. Change your mind and create a folder `src/components`. 7. Move `foo.js` to this folder. ACTUAL: Parcel immediate rebuilds and errors out with can't find `import bar from './bar.js'`. EXPECT: Can Visual Studio move the file and update the imports in an atomic operation so you don't see build failures? This is really easy to reproduce on small web projects running parcel. Parcel takes about 100 to 200 ms to build from what I've seen. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.30.0-insider (9e62a05bc7c5dbb74d165e06f7c3a5f3c7549096, 2018-12-03T06:12:08.874Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

(I hit rate limited from time to time.) VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.30.0-insider (fa87e67ebfd6b8014ba697ddbc6c2d6c0e2cb970, 2018-12-04T09:26:33.257Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.0.0

title: Ability to remove bot suggested duplicates comment
body:
Often (more than half of the time) vscode bot creates a comment containing irrelevant links. It would be great: 

* If bot can monitor upvotes: On downvote from issue author => delete the comment
* If it can't => On comment `/nope` from issue author => delete the comment

Maybe bot can simply automatically delete it in ~3 days after publishing it.

title: consider to allow for variable substitution in the inputs section

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
testing #64214:

I assume that variable substitution in the "inputs" section is disabled to avoid recursion...

However, I think it would be helpful to allow "simple" non-interactive variables like ${env:...}, ${config:...}, ${workspaceFolder:...}. This makes it possible to do something like this:
```
{
			"label": "echoPrompt",
			"description": "Please enter a folder name",
			"default": "${env:HOME}",
			"type": "prompt",
}
```

title: Loaded scripts: session and folder should be a bit more distinguishable
body:
Refs: #64230

In the loaded scripts view if I am debugging multiple sessions how we display sessions and folders is not distuingishable enough. Currently they have these two distinctions:
* sessions do not show a folder icon (which is great, but not visible in the default icon theme)
* sessions have a differetn hover text

I suggest to experiment with prefexing the session title with `Debug Session`
Or to try to prefix the folder label with `../` if that makes sense.
Any other ideas polish that would make them more distungishable would be good imho

![screenshot 2018-12-04 at 12 02 48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/49437735-a04b4580-f7bc-11e8-862e-66c40f3f0a89.png)

title: trackpad two finger scroll ignores windows settings and is way too fast!
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.29.1
- OS Version: 1803 - 17134.407

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a long document
2. Scroll using two fingers on bootcamp macbook trackpad

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

I am running latest available vscode on windows 10 via bootcamp. I have all updates installed. If I try and scroll any portion of vscode using two finger scroll, then the the scrolling speed is incredibly high. Vscode will scroll maybe 5-10 lines at a time. This makes it unusable because even minor movement on the trackpad can scroll like 50 - 100+ lines of code!

Changing the windows mouse wheel settings makes no difference. I currently have it set to 1.

Changing `"window.smoothScrollingWorkaround"` and `"window.titleBarStyle"` makes no difference.

The only thing that helps is changing `"editor.mouseWheelScrollSensitivity"` to `0.3`. This is not viable because then when using a mouse attached to the laptop, the scrolling is too slow. I have to continuously modify this mouse setting when switching between working at desk and working mobile.

No matter what I try I am unable to get smooth or inertial scrolling working.

I have read the other open issues and they seemed to have either been closed, "fixed" or don't apply to this issue.

title: Highlight active file in explorer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It would be nice to have active opened file highlighted in explorer area. Autoreveal is great, but not very handy on big project. For now explorer leaves  last opened file being highlighted.

So, for clarity: When switching between opened files, explorer should highlight current opened file, and **do not move focus** on it (like in current Autoreveal option). Also it can highlight folder if it not expanded (but **not expand** it automatically)

title: Go Language invalid indentation on return
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.29.1 (bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e)
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.1 (18B75)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write source 
```go
package product_test

func ExampleProduct() {
	p, _ := NewProduct(
		"Foo", 
		"Foo is awesome product", 
		decimal.NewFromFloat(10000))|
		
}
```
and put the cursor on column contains "NewFromFloat"

2. Hit return
```go
package product_test

func ExampleProduct() {
	p, _ := NewProduct(
		"Foo", 
		"Foo is awesome product", 
		decimal.NewFromFloat(10000))
		|
}
```
The cursor is under "decimal"

**While expect**, cursor under "p"
```go
package product_test

func ExampleProduct() {
	p, _ := NewProduct(
		"Foo", 
		"Foo is awesome product", 
		decimal.NewFromFloat(10000))
	|
}
```
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

body: Issue Type: Bug Launching code with `--reuse-window` flag Settings ```json "window.newWindowDimensions": "fullscreen", "window.openFilesInNewWindow": "off", "window.openFoldersInNewWindow": "off", "window.openWithoutArgumentsInNewWindow": "off", "window.restoreFullscreen": true, "window.restoreWindows": "all", ``` * Open a workspace (there should be opened editors) * Close all tabs * Open recent => switch to another workspace * New Window is created (2 in total) If you open a workspace with **0** opened tabs - it will reuse the window If you open a workspace with **3**(n) opened tabs and do not close them - it will reuse the window VS Code version: Code 1.29.1 (bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e, 2018-11-15T19:13:36.375Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

title: Snippet Option To Auto Execute on Type
body:
Hi. When adding new snippets, I want to see an option that when checked, will automatically expand the snippet for you. Now I know this can be done by creating a snippet and then binding a key to that snippet command. However, this is limiting since you can't type a string and get it auto expanded. Also, it's a lot more work.

For example when I type `class` I don't want to click tab or enter or choose the snippet suggestion from the widget. I want it to automatically expand to the defined snippet.

------------------------------------------------------------

### This is the closest vscode is to achieving this, however as I said "key" is very limited. What about another field `"triggerOnType": true`? 

```
Assign keybindings to snippets
You can create custom keybindings to insert specific snippets. Open keybindings.json (Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts File), which defines all your keybindings, and add a keybinding passing "snippet" as an extra argumen
{
  "key": "cmd+k 1",
  "command": "editor.action.insertSnippet",
  "when": "editorTextFocus",
  "args": {
    "snippet": "console.log($1)$0"
  }
}
```

title: Replace doesn't insert captures when finding multible lines
body:
Issue Type: Bug If you search in files for regular expressions with capture it doesn't work when matching multible lines. Example: find = (x),[\n\s]*(y); replace = $2 - $1 will change: "x, y;" to: "y - x", so this works. but it will change: "x, y;" to: "$2 - $1". This is literally "$1" and "$2". title: "Stage selected ranges" sometimes stages a revert of changes in the previous commit

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I am not able to test with the insiders build as I don't have permission to install unauthorized software versions on my workstation here.

- VSCode Version: 1.29.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

(Since this seems to be kind of finicky, I've added more details about how I select things and so on than I would ordinarily provide.)

1. Change two different locations in a file.
1. Select the changed lines in one location (with the mouse) and choose **Git: Stage Selected Ranges** from the palette (I open it with Ctrl-Shift-P).
2. Fill in a commit message and commit the change by pressing Ctrl-Enter.
3. Click off the previous selection and select the other change. Again choose **Git: Stage Selected Ranges** from the palette. *Do not do anything else in between* (sometimes the issue does not occur if you do other things).
4. View the staged changes. In addition to the newly staged lines, an exact revert of the previous changes is present. This does get committed if you then commit, and it shows up in `git diff --cached`.

This happens pretty reliably, but only happened 75% of the times I was trying to reproduce it -- I assume I was doing something else in between or selecting something in a slightly different way the times it didn't happen.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

## Git output

VSCode appears to be doing a lot of extra stuff the second time!

On staging the first change:

```
> git show HEAD:git training/Activities/activities.md
> git hash-object --stdin -w --path git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- git training/Activities/activities.md
> git update-index --cacheinfo 100644 3592ee3adb9657ed0ef318abc491cbc19969d7b5
 git training/Activities/activities.md
> git status -z -u
> git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
> git rev-parse pilot/master
> git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name pilot/master@{u}
> git rev-list --left-right pilot/master...refs/remotes/origin/pilot/master
> git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname) --sort -committerdate
> git remote --verbose
> git show :git training/Activities/activities.md
```

On staging the second change:

```
> git hash-object --stdin -w --path git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- git training/Activities/activities.md
> git update-index --cacheinfo 100644 a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
 git training/Activities/activities.md
> git status -z -u
> git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
> git rev-parse pilot/master
> git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name pilot/master@{u}
> git rev-list --left-right pilot/master...refs/remotes/origin/pilot/master
> git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname) --sort -committerdate
> git remote --verbose
> git show :git training/Activities/activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git ls-tree -l HEAD -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git show 29fdbfdab2573936bf25f93dc9d00e36c3079920
> git ls-files --stage -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git show 29fdbfdab2573936bf25f93dc9d00e36c3079920
> git ls-files --stage -- c:\Workspaces\Temp\toolslang_tfs_training\git training\Activities\activities.md
> git cat-file -s a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
> git cat-file -s a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
> git show a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
> git show a4df3ae5acc9dfee9d7b33e8608581ca640715eb
> git show HEAD:git training/Activities/activities.md
> git show :git training/Activities/activities.md
```

title: Double click the left mouse button to select the nearest code block
body: Issue Type: Feature Request Double click the left mouse button to select the nearest code block. How the editor puts the mouse in {}, double-clicking the left mouse button will automatically select the contents inside the curly braces! VS Code version: Code 1.29.1 (bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e, 2018-11-15T19:13:36.375Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
